prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this science goal, we are planning to make 0.2" resolution imaging observation toward TW Hya in continuum emission at Band 7, 13CO(3-2), and 12CO(3-2).
Since the inner part of the TWHya's disk is ~0.4" (see figure 1 in the SJ), the 0.2" resolution is reasonable and we can obtain the radial dependence of the physical quantities.
We observe the molecular lines simultaneously together with continuum emission. We use two basebands for the molecular lines and other for Band 7 continuum. In order to obtain the molecular lines, we use 117 MHz band width backend configuration in the dual polarization mode, which has a maximum velocity resolution of 0.11 km/s in considering the Hanning window funciton. This is significant to achieve our requirement of 0.2 km/s, which is for resolving the disk emission (~1 km/s; Qi et al. 2004).
The required on-source integration time is 3.12 hours in this science goal, which is estimated on the basis of previous submillimeter studies as follows. The desired sensitivity is calculated for the weakest emission line, 13CO(3-2). The 13CO(3-2) integrated intensity of the target is 0.24 K km/s for the 14.4" beam of JCMT (van Zadelhoff et al. 2001). Taking into account for the velocity width of the disk and the disk size of ~200AU (Andrews et al. 2012), the averaged brightness over the disk is 1.32 K. Assuming that a filling factor of each velocity components with respect to the entire of the disk is roughly 0.3, which is estimated from the ALMA SV data of TWHya, the peak brightness temperature is expected to be 4.4 K. Therefore with a sensitivity of 0.88K, we can significantly detect the 13CO(3-2) emission above 5sigma in its channel map and above 10sigma in its radial plot, which satisfy our requirement as described in the SJ.
With this integration time, the continuum sensitivity obtained from line free channels becomes 0.03 mJy/beam. The integrated flux density at Band 7 is 1.34 Jy and the radius of the dust disk is 60 AU (Andrews et al. 2012). Assuming the continuum emission distributes uniformly over the disk, the peak flux density becomes 17.1 mJy/beam. Therefore we can detect the continuum emission at Band 7 above 300sigma on an average. This corresponds to <1% error in surface density, and we can resolve the expected decrement in surface density of 0.01-0.2 (see Figure 2(a) and (b)).

In this science goal, we are planning to make 0.2" resolution imaging observation toward TW Hya in continuum emission at Band 6, 13CO(2-1), and 12CO(2-1). Additionally, we will observe C18O(2-1) simultaneously. Although the C18O emission is usually weak, if it is detected, we can constrain the temperature closer to the disk midplane than 13CO.
We observe the molecular lines simultaneously together with continuum emission. We use three basebands for the molecular lines and other for Band 6 continuum. In order to obtain the molecular lines, we use 117 MHz bandwidth backend configuration in the dual polarization mode, which has a maximum velocity resolution of 0.16 km/s in considering the Hanning window function. This is significant to achieve our requirement of 0.2 km/s, which is for resolving the disk emission (~1 km/s; Qi et al. 2004).
The required on-source integration time is 4.30 hours in this science goal, which is estimated on the basis of previous submillimeter studies. The desired sensitivity is calculated for the 13CO(2-1) line because it is usually much weaker than 12CO(2-1).
The 13CO(2-1) integrated intensity is 2.7 Jy (=0.93 K) over the 8"x8" region around TW HYa (Favre et al. 2013). Taking into account for the velocity width of the disk and the disk size of ~200AU (Andrews et al. 2012), the averaged brightness over the disk is 1.32 K. Assuming that a filling factor of each velocity components with respect to the entire of the disk is roughly 0.3, which is estimated from the ALMA SV data of TWHya, the peak brightness temperature is expected to be 5.5 K. Therefore with a sensitivity of 1.1 K, we can significantly detect the 13CO(2-1) emission above 5sigma in its channel map and above 10sigma in its radial plot, which satisfy our requirement as described in the SJ.
With this integration time, the continuum sensitivity obtained from line free channels becomes 0.01 mJy/beam. The integrated flux density at Band 6 is 0.57 Jy and the radius of the dust disk is 60 AU (Qi et al. 2004, Andrews et al. 2012). Assuming the continuum emission distributes uniformly over the disk, the peak flux density becomes 6.7 mJy/beam. Therefore we can detect the continuum emission at Band 6 above 300sigma on an average. This corresponds to <1% error in surface density, and we can resolve the expected decrement in surface density of 0.01-0.2 (see Figure 2(a) and (b)).

In this science goal, we are planning to make 0.2" resolution imaging observation toward HD169142 in continuum emission at Band 6, 13CO(2-1), and 12CO(3-2). Additionally, we will observe C18O(2-1) simultaneously. Although the C18O emission is usually weak, if it is detected, we can constrain the temperature closer to the disk midplane than 13CO.
We observe the molecular lines simultaneously together with continuum emission. We use three basebands for the molecular lines and other for Band 6 continuum. In order to obtain the molecular lines, we use 117 MHz bandwidth backend configuration in the dual polarization mode, which has a maximum velocity resolution of 0.08 km/s in considering the Hanning window function. This is significant to achieve our requirement of 0.2 km/s, which is for resolving the disk emission (~2.0 km/s; Panic et al. 2008).
The required on-source integration time is 58 minutes in this science goal, which is estimated on the basis of previous submillimeter studies. The desired sensitivity is calculated for the 13CO(2-1) line because it is usually much weaker than 12CO(2-1).
The peak intensity of 13CO(2-1) is 6.5 Jy km/s (=11.6 K km/s) over the 4"x4" region around HD 169142 (Panic et al. 2008). Taking into account for the velocity width of the disk and the disk a disk size of 235 AU (Raman et al. 2006), the averaged brightness over the disk is 10.5 K. With a sensitivity of 2.1 K, we can significantly detect the 13CO(2-1) emission above 5sigma in its channel map and above 10sigma in its radial plot, which satisfy our requirement as described in the SJ.
With this integration time, the continuum sensitivity obtained from line free channels becomes 0.03 mJy/beam. The integrated flux density at Band 6 is 0.169 Jy and the radius of the dust disk is ~0.5" (Raman et al. 2006). Assuming the continuum emission distributes uniformly over the disk, the peak flux density becomes 8.3 mJy/beam. Therefore we can detect the continuum emission at Band 6 above 300sigma on an average. This corresponds to <1% error in surface density, and we can resolve the expected decrement in surface density of 0.01-0.2 (see Figure 2(a) and (b)).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose 0.2arcsec multi-band imagings toward protoplanetary disks, TW Hya and HD 169142, in continuum and molecular lines at Band 6 and 7. Our NIR survey with Subaru (SEEDS project) has revealed that these sources show an annular gap in their scattered disk at R~0.4arcsec. Although the origin of the annular gap is still unclear, it can be interpreted by the irregularity in the scattered surface due to change in either surface density or temperature distribution in an inner region of the disk. Since the it cannot be directly resolved from the NIR data, (sub-)millimeter observations come to be crucial.
Thus our proposal aims: (1) to determine from continuum observations whether the surface density at the inner region decreases or not. By deriving the distribution of dust mass opacity and temperature with multi-band continuum and molecular line observations, we will constrain the surface density distribution. (2) to find the temperature variation through the NIR gap from multi-transition molecular line observations. With these observations, we can confirm the origin of the NIR gap and will discuss disk evolution and the possibility of planet formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Liberal Arts, Kogakuin University
